review.title: Sentiment Analysis in Scholarly Book Reviews
review.abstract: So far different studies have tackled the sentiment analysis in several domains such as restaurant and movie reviews. But, this problem has not been studied in scholarly book reviews which is different in terms of review style and size. In this paper, we propose to combine different features in order to be presented to a supervised classifiers which extract the opinion target expressions and detect their polarities in scholarly book reviews. We construct a labeled corpus for training and evaluating our methods in French book reviews. We also evaluate them on English restaurant reviews in order to measure their robustness across the domains and languages. The evaluation shows that our methods are enough robust for English restaurant reviews and French book reviews.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The classification of opinion at the document or sentence level is not sufficient for applications that need to identify the opinion objectives. Even if it is a unit, many applications need to determine the opinion on every aspect of the unit. A user can express a positive opinion on the food in a restaurant, but he can have a negative opinion on other aspects such as the ambience. Therefore, we need to identify the aspects and determine whether the mood is positive, negative or neutral to everyone. This task is called Aspect-based Sentiment Analysis or Feature-Based Opinion Mining, as it is called in the early work [Hu and Liu, 2004].In this work we address the problem of sentiment analysis in scientific book reviews. Our goal is to extract the opinion expressed in relation to a book in all its reviews. Therefore, in view of a collection of book reviews, we aim to express the aspects of the book and the mood in relation to each aspect.

sections.heading: 3 Opinion Target Extraction
sections.text: This extraction consists of the following steps: 1. Review Segmentation This step segments each review into sentences. 2. Sentence Tokenizing Each sentence is symbolized to obtain the terms. 3. Sentence Tagging Each term in the sentence should be marked to be presented to a tagging classifier. We select IOB notation to represent each sentence in the review. Therefore, we distinguish the terms at the beginning, the inside and the outside of the opinion goal. For example, for the following review set: "Mais la méthode avec laquelle il presenté comme seule hypothèserecevable pose." Where méthode is a goal: The day of each word becomes: Mais la: O méthode: O laquelle.

sections.heading: 3.1 Experiments and Results
sections.text: The first line represents the experiment when only the terms are used as attributes, resulting in an F1 score of 49.5%; the second line, Word + POS, uses the term and POStagging as attributes, which improves results and reaches 61.2%; the third line uses the term, POS tags, types and form attributes, which improve the previous run by 0.3%; the fourth line uses all attributes, including term, POS, form, type and prefix and suffix, which results in 61.5%; so it should be noted that the word and POS attributes seem sufficient to achieve a good result; and the last line shows the results of applying our system to SemEval-2015 restaurant reviews [Rosenthal et al., 2015].

sections.heading: 3.2 Sentiment Polarity
sections.text: For a given set of opinion goals within a sentence, we should determine whether the polarity of each opinion goal is positive, negative or neutral. For example, the system should extract the polarity of the method in the following sentence: "Mais la méthode avec laquelle il est présenté comme seule hypothèse recevablepose problème." méthode: negativeWe propose to use a logistic regression with the following characteristics: - Word-grams characteristics Unigrams, Bigrams and 3-grams are extracted for each word in context, without ancestry or stop-word removal, all terms with an occurrence of less than 3 are removed from the attribute space.- Z-characteristics As described in [Hamdan et al., 2014a], we tested different thresholds for selecting the words that have the highest Z-rating, a grid search in the interval [-2.. 5] with a higher class of 0.5 after we found the best number of the two words in 0.5.

sections.heading: 3.3 Experiments
sections.text: The results are in Table 3. The last two lines show the results obtained in applying our system to restaurant and laptop reviews provided by SemEval2015 [Rosenthal et al., 2015] The first line represents the experiment in which only the terms are used as characteristics, giving an accuracy value of 70%. The remaining lines represent the experiments in using the word and Z-Score characteristics, each line represents the same experiment but with a different Z-threshold. We start by assigning 3 to Z-Score threshold and lowering this threshold to -1. The best result is achieved when using terms and Z-Score characteristics with a Z-threshold of -0.5. Accuracy is 79%, which seems fair compared to the results in restaurant reviews (approximately 75.5%).

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: We compiled a corpus of book reviews, divided each review into sentences and asked three commentators to extract the opinion goals and their polarities in each sentence. We trained a CRF model for opinion goal extraction and a logistical regression one for mood polarity. The results obtained indicate that our systems work just as well as in restaurant reviews.
